summary: all captured bats were anesthetized with an intraperitoneal injection (15 mg/kg) of tiletamine and zolazepam (Virbac, Carros, France) and killed by cardiac exsanguination. the experiment was conducted in accordance with the guidelines for the care and use of laboratory animals. PCR amplicons were gel purified by using NucleoSpin Extract II. cloned by using a TOPO-TA pCR2.1 Cloning Kit (Invitrogen) sequences were performed in an ABI 3130 XL DNA analyzer. experimentally infected bats were examined daily for clinical signs of infection. a sample of large intestine from a lesser dog-faced fruit bat was homogenized in a mortar. the supernatant was used for oral infection. quantitative real-time PCR was performed by using 0.5 L total RNA and the PrimeScript RT Reagent Kit (TaKaRa, Shiga, Japan) the temperature program consisted of an initial denaturation at 95°C for 10 min, followed by 40 cycles at 95°C for 15 s and 60°C for 1 min. extracted RNA was eluted in 50 L of RNase-free water. for cDNA synthesis, RNA (5 L), a random hexamer, and a superScript III kit were used. RNA of group 1b bat CoV was detected in 4 (57.1%) of 7 insectivorous bats. all bats positive for group 1b bat CoV belonged to the same species, the Lesser Asiatic yellow bat (Scotophilus kuhlii) the partial RdRp sequence of the virus was most similar to that of bat-CoV/China/A515/2005. we tried to isolate bat CoVs from several cell lines and primary cultured cells. however, virus replication was not observed, which is consistent with results of a previous report (17). compared with primary infection by field samples obtained from C. brachyotis, the level of viral genome amplification was low. this finding may have been caused by a difference in viral replication in bats of different species.
